We offer the same level of commitment no matter the trial, including cases of:  -business litigation -product liability -wrongful death -medical negligence -aviation litigation -employment litigation -nursing home neglect litigation  We demand the best settlements. Our nursing home neglect and abuse attorneys of Kentucky take great pride in representing residents and their families who have suffered as a result of a facility’s failure and neglect to properly care for those individuals who cannot care for themselves. We are here to protect victims. Trust Hare, Wynn, Newell & Newton, LLP. Lawyers helping people  -- since 1890.

Lehr Middlebrooks & Vreeland is a full-service law firm that specializes in the areas of labor and employment law. The firm serves the residents of the United States, Alaska, New Zealand and Australia. It resolves immigration, appellate practice, business restructuring and government contractor issues. Lehr Middlebrooks & Vreeland also offers assistance in protecting trade secrets, customer lists and technologies. The firm represents employers during inspection, enforcement, rule making and variance proceedings. It provides a range of counseling solutions concerning deferred compensation retirement plans. Lehr Middlebrooks & Vreeland handles a selection of administrative matters before the National Labor Relations Board. The firm s clients include the Xerox Corporation, Palco Telecommunications, Three Springs and Simply Fashion Stores.

Business Name: Cabaniss Johnston Gardner Dumas And O'Neal
Business Information: Cabaniss, Johnston, Gardner, Dumas & O'Neal is one of the oldest law firms in Alabama that offers a range of legal services. Its clients include Castrol Industrial North America, Gorrie Regan & Associates, JP Morgan Chase Bank, Liberty National Life Insurance Company, Medical Center East and St. Clair Regional Hospital. The firm serves the concrete and cement, heating and cooling, hospitals and health care, natural gas, coal mining, oil and gas, real estate, retail and nursing industries. Its practice areas include bankruptcy and corporate reorganization, labor and employment, estates and trusts, litigation, municipal law and taxation. Cabaniss, Johnston, Gardner, Dumas & O'Neal has been operational for more than 120 years and maintains locations in Birmingham and Mobile, AL.

For over 38 years, Haskell Slaughter has provided sophisticated advice and aggressive representation to meet the needs of public companies, private businesses, state and local governments and individuals.

Baker, Donelson, Bearman, Caldwell & Berkowitz is a law firm. Its practice areas include antitrust, bankruptcy, estate planning, taxation, litigation, public finance, public policy and government investigations. The firm also offers services in the areas of intellectual property, immigration, employment, employee benefits, environmental and health laws. Its services for businesses cover planning, corporate compliance, venture capital, and mergers and acquisitions. The firm s intellectual property group obtains, defends and enforces patents, trademarks and copyrights in the United States and foreign countries. Its services for the construction sector include counseling and assisting clients with contract negotiation, bidding, dispute avoidance and dispute resolution. The firm s office is located in Birmingham, Ala.

Community and charitable involvement are important to Burr & Forman. Along with its more general support to a variety of charities, in each city where the law firm is located it selects one charity that receives even more concentrated effort. At present, Burr & Forman s impact charities are Kid One Transport Systems and Camp Sunshine. Burr & Forman provides legal services to clients in a variety of industries including real estate, banking, health care, financial services, construction, pharmaceutical and automotive. Areas of practice the firm specialize in include business law, creditor s rights, economic development, estate and tax planning, litigation, sports and entertainment and Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act compliancy. The firm has offices in Atlanta; Birmingham and Montgomery, Ala.; and Jackson, Miss. Burr & Forman was founded in 1905.

Business Name: Siegal , Bradley G. - Leitman, Siegal, Payne & Campbell, P.C
Business Information: Leitman, Siegal & Payne is a law firm that specializes in handling matters related to corporate, real estate, taxation labor and employment law. It assists clients in issues concerning employee benefit claims and estate, probate and pension planning. The firm s litigation practice group handles matters related to antitrust and trade regulations, bankruptcy and creditors  rights, and disputes that arise in the formation, operation and dissolution of partnerships, joint ventures and corporations. In addition, it deals with issues related to franchise, insurance, securities, and land use and zoning litigation, as well as professional malpractice and business tort. The firm s attorneys are members of the American Bar Association, Alabama Bar Association and Birmingham Bar Association. Founded in 1976, Leitman, Siegal & Payne is located in Birmingham, Ala.

Burr & Forman LLP is a full-service law firm providing legal solutions located in Birmingham, Ala. The firm has offices in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and Tennessee. Burr & Forman LLP offers a wide range of business and litigation services to diverse clients with local, national and international interests. The firm offers a wide range of services that include class action, commercial litigation, condominium law, construction, corporate law and business planning, to name a few. In 2010, ALM named Burr & Forman LLP in the "AmLaw 200" as one of the United States top 200 law firms.

Maynard Cooper & Gale is a law firm that offers a broad range of business services, including mergers and acquisitions, charitable foundations, tax, estates and trusts, venture capital, private equity, technology, intellectual property, commercial lending, real estate, securities and health care. The firm regularly performs litigation services in disputes including contracts, federal and state securities, fraud, bad faith, environmental, labor, tort, product liability, real estate, bankruptcy, and antitrust issues. The firm was founded in 1984 by 26 attorneys who had formerly practiced together at one of the oldest and largest firms in Alabama. The firm has grown to more than 140 attorneys and is located in Birmingham, Ala.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.
General civil practice, public finance, bankruptcy, real estate, estate planning, construction, corporate law, tax law, insurance law, banking law

Sirote & Permutt is a law firm that provides legal services, including bankruptcy, corporate, insurance, environment, health care, computer, civil trial and intellectual property law. The firm began its long history in 1946 following World War II when Morris Sirote and Edward Friend, Jr. joined forces with James Permutt to establish a law office in Birmingham, Ala. The company has more than 300 attorneys. It has offices in Huntsville and Mobile, Ala. The firm has a commitment to diversity in the workplace and of its 104 shareholders and associates, 28 percent are women and minorities. Sirote & Permutt has received the United Way Chairman's Award.

A Birmingham tax attorney at Palmer,  Meadows & Howell will help solve I.R.S. tax debt while providing  diligent representation to clients in U.S. Tax Court litigation, I.R.S.  appeals, offer in compromise, liens, levy, innocent spouse relief and  other tax relief.  The firm includes a former I.R.S. attorney who is "of  counsel."  The firm's lawyers also represent clients in state tax  matters involving the Alabama Department of Revenue. Although the firm is well known for tax  law, Palmer, Meadows & Howell is a full service law firm that will  strive to reach a favorable conclusion for your every legal  need.  Contact the firm to speak with a Birmingham tax attorney about  your case, or to speak with a lawyer who specializes in our other  practice areas.  Palmer, Meadows & Howell is located in Birmingham,  Alabama.

Trimmier Law Firm represents corporations, credit unions, individuals and trade associations. The firm serves as General Counsel for more credit unions than any other firm in the country. The firm's relationship with the Alabama Credit Union League expanded the Firm to cities throughout Alabama to better serve its clients' needs. The representation of the Florida Credit Union League again expanded the Firm into the state of Florida. Since 1997, the Firm has expanded its services to Louisiana credit unions affiliated with the Louisiana Credit Union League. Members of the Firm have represented credit unions since 1971 Trimmier Law Firm is located within the Highland Park Historic District of Birmingham. For further information on the services provided by the firm, please visit the "Practice Areas" heading above.

Gregory Fann Turner provides both mediation and legal services in the areas of business disputes, family disputes, products liability claims, contract claims and other complex civil litigation. The firm represents both individuals and small businesses primarily in complex litigation matters. Brian Turner is an experienced mediator in the areas of civil and family litigation. This brings a unique perspective to our legal practice, having represented both plaintiffs and defendants in many types of litigation as well as having served as a neutral in a dispute resolution setting.

Sprain Law Firm, P.C. is a general practice law firm located in Homewood, Alabama within a few miles of the downtown Birmingham commercial district. The firm is committed to providing efficient and effective legal services to a broad range of clients. The firm's two primary practice areas are general civil defense of corporations and businesses and real estate development and transactions. Our defense work includes defending several large corporations in product liability law suits throughout the State of Alabama. Our real estate practice includes both residential and commercial and our clients include banks, developers, shopping center owners and real estate brokers. This web site is designed for general information only. The information presented at this site should not be construed to be formal legal advice nor the formation of a lawyer/client relationship. Sprain Law Firm, PC website is powered by LexisNexis Martindale-Hubbell. Sitemap

Belt, Bruner & Barnett, P.C. is a personal injury law firm in Birmingham, Alabama. Our Birmingham personal injury attorneys have a proven track record of maximizing results in a variety of personal injury cases. We're accomplished and respected trial lawyers with courtroom experience. Our injury lawyers have obtained verdicts and settlements of $1million or greater in more than 75 different cases arising from car accidents, truck wrecks, medical malpractice, dog bites, and other cases.

Riley & Jackson, P.C. helps people, businesses, and local governments at the time they need it most. By representing individuals in cases involving wrongful death, catastrophic personal injury, securities claims, and nursing home and medical malpractice, the firm furthers its purpose of serving those in need. When advocating on behalf of businesses involved in litigation and commercial disputes, our lawyers call on decades of experience with issues unique to small businesses. Riley & Jackson attorneys have also successfully represented numerous local governments. The firm has filed and defended cases for counties, cities and sheriffs in multiple states.

Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. In 1981, Mr. May received his Juris Doctor degree from Birmingham School of Law where he ranked among the top ten students of his class and graduated Magna Cum Laude. While in law school, Mr. May received two American Jurisprudence awards for excellent achievement in the study of law. In 1983, Mr. May was certified by the United States Patent and Trademark Office as a registered patent attorney entitling him to practice before that Office. Mr. May’s background and experience include nine years as an engineer for a large Alabama firm where he progressed to the position of engineering specialist on the managerial staff before deciding to join the firm of Allison, May & Kimbrough. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.

Founded in 1943, Dominick, Fletcher, Yeilding, Wood & Lloyd is a full-service law firm. Its practice areas include banking and finance, business law, land use, wills, trusts, financial and estate planning, taxation, commercial litigation, labor and employment, intellectual property, and fiduciary and construction disputes. Dominick, Fletcher, Yeilding, Wood & Lloyd maintains a location in Birmingham, Ala.

Benton & Centeno, LLP is a full service law firm located in Birmingham, Alabama, representing and advising clients in the areas of bankruptcy, construction, business and commercial litigation, in every level of state and federal courts, as well as arbitration.

Business Name: Over The Mountain Law Center LLC
Business Information: Birmingham Bankruptcy Attorneys,  Birmingham Chapter 7 Attorneys, Birmingham Chapter 13 Attorneys, Alabama Chapter 7 Lawyers, Alabama Chapter 13 Lawyers,  Birmingham Bankruptcy Law Firm, Birmingham Debt Relief.

Dynamic Legal Recovery is a vigorous account receivable recovery firm and debt collection firm affiliated with over 3000 attorneys, investigative professionals, paralegals and master collectors who specialize in creditors rights on a global scale.  Our fees are very simple; there is no one size fits all. We have found that every situation is different and our contingent fee is based on the size of accounts, age, volume, and forward flow.  On business accounts, 80% of what we collect is PAID in the first two weeks.   We have developed a proprietary collection system that has an immediate and demonstrable impact which has been perfected to get you paid. Our masterful knowledge and experience equip DLR to get you the immediate results you deserve.   Terry Taylor, our founder, and CEO will personally handle your large claims. He has an impressive record of being responsible for the collection of over 1 billion dollars during his collection career.

Our office has the ability to turn your slow paying, delinquent and out of touch clients receivables into cash. We work in the areas of contract law, business litigation and collections. Our in-house counsel’s main focus areas are litigation, contract law, and legal research motivated by our strong will to collect hundreds of thousands of dollars for our clients, from dunning letters and standard collection practices to formal litigation, our debt collection firm and their professionals support you throughout the entire process. We assist you to retain a positive working relationship with your clients by providing a non-contentious solution with our velvet glove approach.

I work closely with my clients to ensure that their cases are handled effectively, efficiently, and compassionately. In addition to my more than 20 years of employment law experience, I handled commercial litigation for several years early in my career. This experience has broadened my understanding of how businesses function and who the defend employment law litigation.

In operation since 2000, Christian & Small is a full-service law firm. It offers a range of counseling and litigation services. The firm represents clients in cases related to antitrust, bankruptcy, business transactions, domestic relations, government affairs, insurance, health care, product and liquor liability, real estate, tax, and estate and trust planning. Christian & Small provides legal services to clients in matters that involve trademark infringement, unfair competition, dilution and the misappropriation of trade secrets. It defends individuals and businesses in criminal investigation matters. The firm also defends transportation companies in personal injury, employment, and cargo and property damage cases. In addition, Christian & Small offers advisory services for operating, independent contractor, joint venture and buy-sell agreements, as well as employment contracts.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Business Name: John C Robbins, Attorney at Law
Business Information: I have helped thousands of people achieve successful results with their criminal charges, including more than 200 clients charged with murder. For compassionate criminal defense for homicide, DUI, drug, domestic violence, and white-collar charges, contact my firm — John C. Robbins, LLC — in Birmingham, Alabama today to schedule a free consultation with an experienced attorney.

Street Address: 15 Richard Arrington Jr Blvd N Ste 305
Business Information: Cunningham Firm, LLC was founded as a business and tax transactional firm in October, 2005. Most of the clients of Cunningham Firm, LLC are small to medium sized businesses ( often referred to as "emerging businesses" ) and the owners of such businesses. However, the firm does a variety of work for large corporations ( e.g., representing publicly traded financial institutions in commercial real estate financing transactions and representing publicly traded insurance companies with respect to their local real estate holdings ) as well as non-business owning individuals ( e.g., representing individuals before the Internal Revenue Service or the Alabama Department of Revenue ). Whether the client is an individual or a business, the focus of Cunningham Firm, LLC has always been providing efficient and cost effective legal services. This is important to our clients, because most have a limited budget for legal services. We believe that the daily challenge of solving our client's legal problems on a limited budget makes us a better law firm. We strive to work with a diverse clientele. The diversity of our client base makes our work more interesting and keeps us informed of legal issues facing multiple industries. As part of its commitment to provide quality legal services to its clients, Cunningham Firm, LLC formed the alliance of Red Mountain Law along with other small Birmingham, Alabama law firms in 2006. Membership in this association provides firm clients access to a broader range of legal expertise than would otherwise be available at the firm. For more information about Red Mountain Law, please visit its website at www.redmountainlaw.com.

Founded in 1920, Balch & Bingham is a full-service law firm. It employs more than 250 attorneys and maintains offices in Atlanta; Birmingham and Montgomery, Ala.; Gulfport and Jackson, Miss.; and Washington, D.C. The firm s practice areas include alternative dispute resolution, appellate cases, business and corporate law, commercial finance, federal procurement, financial and estate planning, health care, environmental law and land use. Additionally, Balch & Bingham deals in white-collar defense, intellectual property, labor and employment, real estate, mergers and acquisitions, export controls and economic sanctions, taxation law, insurance claims, venture capital and antitrust litigation. The firm offers various pro bono services and participates in several fundraising activities.

Founded in 2001, Alexander Shunnarah Injury Lawyer, P.C. is one of the premium law firms in Alabama and the southeastern United States. It deals in a variety of legal cases, such as personal injury, wrongful death, workers compensation, criminal defense and product liability issues. The firm specializes in the field of personal injury, including car accidents, truck accidents, workers compensation and multiple personal injuries. Alexander Shunnarah Injury Lawyer, P.C. is a member of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, Alabama Association for Justice, Alabama State Bar and Birmingham Bar Association.
Practice Areas: Medical Malpractice Class Action Personal Injury Products Liability Business Litigation Complex Litigation Estate & Trust

The firm's banking attorneys advise banks, mortgage companies, and other financial institutions of all sizes, both within and outside the state of Alabama.  The firm also serves as local counsel for banks from other states. Lawyers in the group represent lenders and borrowers in financing transactions of all types, including: commercial mortgages, asset-based lending, tax credits for low income housing, and letter of credit transactions.

Starnes Davis Florie LLP was founded in 1975 and devoted its practice to litigation. The firm has more than 50 attorneys and still specializes in civil litigation practice. Starnes Davis Florie represents physicians, attorneys, architects, accountants, corporations, insurances and multiple other professionals. Its main office is in Birmingham, Ala., and also has a presence in Mobile, Ala. Starnes Davis Florie handles litigation matters throughout the entire state. The law firm recruits law students through a summer program and interviews potential recruits at statewide universities and colleges.

Established in 1975, Starnes Davis Florie LLP provides legal services. Located in Birmingham, Ala., the firm is one of the leading firms in Alabama. Its areas of practice are alternative dispute resolution, appellate, written advocacy, aviation, banking, financial services and biotechnology/pharmaceutical cases. It is involved in handling of insurance coverage opinions, insurance coverage disputes and declaratory judgment actions, among others. Starnes Davis Florie LLP clients list includes corporations, hospitals, banks/municipalities to doctors, attorneys, architects and accountants.

Business Name: Porterfield Harper Mills Motlow & Ireland PA
Business Information: Porterfield, Harper, Mills & Motlow is a full-service law firm that provides client services in various practice areas. Its clients include individuals, businesses, nonprofit organizations and government entities. The firm provides legal services in cases of car and motorcycle accidents, slips and falls, construction site injuries, premise liability, insurance claim denials, medical malpractice, wrongful death, workers  compensation, nursing home negligence and construction defects. Porterfield, Harper, Mills & Motlow additionally provides legal services in the areas of appellate cases, civil rights, white-collar criminal defense, product liability, discrimination, labor and employment, insurance defense and environmental issues. Massey, Stotser & Nichols was initially created in 1977. Timothy A. Massey founded the firm in 1977, and he and Garrick L. Stotser formed Massey & Stotser in 1990. Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. In 1981, Mr. May received his Juris Doctor degree from Birmingham School of Law where he ranked among the top ten students of his class and graduated Magna Cum Laude. While in law school, Mr. May received two American Jurisprudence awards for excellent achievement in the study of law. In 1983, Mr. May was certified by the United States Patent and Trademark Office as a registered patent attorney entitling him to practice before that Office. Mr. May’s background and experience include nine years as an engineer for a large Alabama firm where he progressed to the position of engineering specialist on the managerial staff before deciding to join the firm of Allison, May & Kimbrough. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Whether the client is an individual or a business, the focus of Cunningham Firm, LLC has always been providing efficient and cost effective legal services. We believe that the daily challenge of solving our client's legal problems on a limited budget makes us a better law firm. We strive to work with a diverse clientele. The diversity of our client base makes our work more interesting and keeps us informed of legal issues facing multiple industries. Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. While in law school, Mr. May received two American Jurisprudence awards for excellent achievement in the study of law. In 1983, Mr. May was certified by the United States Patent and Trademark Office as a registered patent attorney entitling him to practice before that Office. Mr. May’s background and experience include nine years as an engineer for a large Alabama firm where he progressed to the position of engineering specialist on the managerial staff before deciding to join the firm of Allison, May & Kimbrough. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. In 1983, Mr. May was certified by the United States Patent and Trademark Office as a registered patent attorney entitling him to practice before that Office. Mr. May’s background and experience include nine years as an engineer for a large Alabama firm where he progressed to the position of engineering specialist on the managerial staff before deciding to join the firm of Allison, May & Kimbrough. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.

The law firm of Beddow, Erben & Bowen, PA has its origins in 1895, twenty five years after the founding of the City of Birmingham in 1871. Although the early focus of the practice was criminal defense, as the years, partners and associates have come and gone, our practice area has grown to incorporate business law, civil litigation, matrimonial and family law, and probate matters.  The firm's rich history includes members of the 1901 Alabama Constitutional Convention, the 10th Judicial Circuit Court, and the Alabama Supreme Court. Our members have been past presidents of the Alabama Bar Association, Committee members of the Legal Aid Board tasked with the establishment of Legal Aid Clinics, as well as the Grievance and Ethics Committee, and the Alabama State Bar Fee Arbitration Committee.  Our firm is well known for never shying away from representing unpopular clients. Periodically, such representation would result in the creation of important new law. For example, our involvement in the 1964 New York Times v. Sullivan case, resulted in a United States Supreme Court decision which established the actual malice standard in libel and defamation law and is a key decision supporting freedom of the press.  Beddow, Erben and Bowen, PA is the firm it is now because of Frederick A. Erben who has practiced here since he was admitted to the Bar in 1966. Through his leadership, our practice has and will continue to expand beyond its original focus. During his tenure, he was mentored by Roderick Beddow, Jr., and practiced with other lawyers who have since become Circuit Court and Alabama Supreme Court justices. Among other milestones during his practice, Mr. Erben and the firm participated in Civil Rights era cases, argued before the first Jefferson County Alabama jury to include women, and won sizeable monetary judgments against corporations, cities and insurance companies. Because of the influence of our talented past and present members, we are currently a firm uniquely prepared to handle almost any legal issue for any client.

Founded over 150 years ago, Bradley’s Birmingham office retains the tradition of Southern hospitality even as the firm has grown into a global legal force. Bradley’s first and largest office was founded in 1870 in Elyton, Alabama, before eventually moving to the newly established city of Birmingham in 1871. Home to a number of legal trailblazers, the firm’s ranks have included founding partner John P. Tillman, who served as the first president of the Birmingham Bar Association in 1885 and as president of the Alabama Bar Association from 1897 to 1898, and Ellene Winn, who in 1958 became one of the first female partners in a major law firm in the Southeast. The Birmingham office currently supports more than 100 charitable organizations across central Alabama. In 2022, the office launched the Black Small Business and Nonprofit Community Clinic, a joint project of Bradley and Legal Services Alabama (LSA), to provide accessible and affordable business-oriented legal services to local Black small businesses and nonprofits across the Magic City.

Wm. Randall (Randy) May  Wm. Randall May is a 1976 graduate of Auburn University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. Mr. May’s background and experience include nine years as an engineer for a large Alabama firm where he progressed to the position of engineering specialist on the managerial staff before deciding to join the firm of Allison, May & Kimbrough. Mr. May is also the past president of the Shelby County Bar Association and is a member of the Birmingham Bar Association and the Alabama State Bar Association where he has served on a number of committees. Mr. May is involved in various legal and community activities and associations and has been an active member of the Volunteer Lawyers Program for over thirteen years. Mr. May is a 2009 graduate of Leadership Shelby County and is the recipient of the 2011 Special Projects Recognition award from the Birmingham Bar Volunteer Lawyers Program for pro bono legal services. Mr. May has also served as a member of the Alabama Board of Bar Commissioners on behalf of the Shelby County Bar Association since 2011.
